pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:0.4: 2–8. The training rules on asking for oil … honey … syrup … fish … meat … milk … curd
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.2: the nuns from the group of six were eating oil that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.3: … were eating honey that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.4: … were eating syrup that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.5: … were eating fish that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.6: … were eating meat that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.7: … were drinking milk that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.8: … were eating curd that they had asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.10: “How can nuns eat curd that they have asked for?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.11: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t prefer tasty food?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.12: The nuns heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.13: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.14: “How can the nuns from the group of six eat curd that they have asked for?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.15: “Is it true, monks, that those nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.18: “… How can the nuns from the group of six do this?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.19: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.20: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.21.1: ‘If a nun asks for curd and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.22: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing that is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.1.23: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.1: Soon afterwards a number of nuns were sick.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.2: The nuns who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.4: “Previously we ate curd that we had asked for, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.5: But now that the Buddha has prohibited this, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.6: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.7: “Monks, I allow a sick nun to eat curd that she has asked for.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.8: And so, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:1.2.9.1: ‘If a nun who is not sick asks for (oil …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:1.1.1: curd and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:1.1.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing that is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.8: who is not comfortable without curd.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.10: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.16: what lives in water is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.18: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.20: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.23: If she is not sick and she asks for herself, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.24: When she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.1.25: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.1: If she is not sick, and she does not perceive herself as sick, and she eats curd that she has asked for, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.2: If she is not sick, but she is unsure of it, and she eats curd that she has asked for, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.3: If she is not sick, but she perceives herself as sick, and she eats curd that she has asked for, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.4: If she is sick, but she does not perceive herself as sick, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.5: If she is sick, but she is unsure of it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.2.6: If she is sick, and she perceives herself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.3: if she asked for it when she was sick, but eats it when she is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.4: if she eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.6: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.7: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.8: if it is by means of her own property;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.10: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.11: The eighth training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.12: “Venerables, the eight rules on acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.13: In regard to this I ask you,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.19: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd8:2.3.20: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment in the nuns’ analysis is finished.
